For security reasons it is now possible to specify SCD user ID for the configuration parameter CfgSvcGrantAllTasks.
Syntax:
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=Enabled [;SCDID]
Enabled: 0 or 1
SCDID: SCD user ID

To be backward compatible the old syntax is still valid.

Examples:
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=1 (the option is enabled)
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=1;SCDID1 (the option is enabled if the current SCD user is SCDID1, for all other users it will be disabled).

This defect fixes the AOCI amortization amount when the previous AOCI Allocation is done on a term date (together with the opening buy). Interest Appreciation day calculation is +1 day. - The fix ensures that the repay on the term date is NOT taken into account in the synthetic cash flow for the AOCI Allocation.  Which changes the yield for the AOCI Allocation!  - The error was reported for 'Fair Value Macro' Hedge type. But the fix is done for all AOCI hedge types, and will affect the transaction AOCI Allocation, AOCI Opening Balance, AOCI Replace and AOCI Update!

-batch=XYZ can now be called with a new command line parameter -ba_stopqueued.
 -batch=XYS -ba_stopqueued: will update all XYZ jobs on all queued jobs on the batch queue to On hold.
 -batch=XYS -ba_stopqueued=ABC: will update all XYZ queued jobs on the ABC batch queue to Deleted.
 It can be called in combination with -ba_stop that will stop running jobs.

New parameters have been added to the batch task ‘Verify Database Structure’.

Force ALTER TABLE: Used to force alter table on tables
Tables: If specified only the tables/table groups listed will be checked
File and Reference File: File with tables/table groups to check.

Only Tables, File or Reference File should be used. If used only tables/table groups within the list will be checked (use semicolon as separator, or for files new line). Wildcard % can be used for both tables and table groups. Table groups must be prefixed with #. E.g. SECURITIES,TRANS%;#Accouting, will check SECURITIES, all tables starting with TRANS and all tables in the Accounting table group.

In this performance test, time thresholds were defined for updating the Internal and External Collateral Inventories.
There are 4 positions, and for each position, 100 prices are imported.

The SmartQueue in the Collateral Event Resolver merges inventory update requests and fetches them, triggering calls to the Collateral Worker Service to update the Internal Inventory.
Updating the Internal Inventory, in turn, triggers a request to update the Remote External Inventory.

Both inventory update processes are timeboxed, and the test verifies that all updates are completed within the specified time thresholds.

On TAA validation step we always fill parent node from child ones in case TAA is 'Bottom-up'. These validated and possibly changed weights has to be saved into application but they were not. As a result, user could save wrong TAA with weights that do not sum up to 100% on parent node. Solution is to save weights changed on validation step on TAA import application, so that on save step we are saving corrected weights into TAA.

Currently dynamic reconciliation fields saved in database as a string. So, before save we convert numbers into strings.  Small values with more than 6 decimals saved in scientific notation. For example, number 0.0000001 will be saved as string '1E¯7'. That could lead to the problem when user wants to work with raw data from database. We will stop to use scientific notation. So, number 0.0000001 will be saved as string '0.0000001'.

The key used to encrypt AZ Connect strings in the Messaging System Settings Window (persisted to the tDESTINATIONCONFIG table) was created by the Installation ID and customer number. This ment that the encrypted connection string could be saved in a master installation, and cloned to other SLE's, because the decryption would then use a different key, and would crash.

Therefore we now use the same key to encrypt (using "INTERNALINSTALLATION" and 0), when encrypting the AZ Connection strings, in internal installations, so connection strings encrypted on a master installation, can now be decrypted on a cloned installation/SLE.

This concerns the ability to correct existing proceeds for CFD's. The proceed and proceed payment transactions may find themselves on different sides on the date condition that decides if transactions should be  deleted, resulting in the system only trying to delete one of them. Now they are treated as a pair of transactions in this respect meaning that if one is marked for deletion the other one will also be deleted.

When the 'Do not calculate incomplete periods' check box was selected in the Performance Reports, rolling extra fields with return basis specified would in the following scenario produce a zero result for a node even though the whole rolling period was complete:
- When the node entered the calculation after the initial date.
- And when the node entered on the last business day of a return basis period, for example the last business day of a month when the return basis period is set to be one month.
- And when calculating for the very first complete rolling period, for example one year after the node entered for a one year rolling period.
- And when the ‘From date’ was set to be one of the days of the last return basis period, for example one of the days of the twelfth month for a one year rolling period.
This has been resolved so that instead of always producing a zero result in above mentioned case, a non-zero result might be calculated.

Synthetic FX Hedge Return Calculation Settings currently supports four price methods that place the entire market value of the FX forward contract on one leg. It will therefore be the single leg that holds the entire P/L and return of the contract. There is, however, a conceptual problem with these methods, since the start of day market value on the value bearing leg is also zero. TWR is therefore not well defined on the opening date when using these price methods. The existing calculation applies a trick where the return is calculated on each leg and then simply subtracted from each other and put to the value bearing leg. One way to understand this approach is that it calculates a unitized P/L for each leg and moves these to the single leg. This approach is, however, difficult to understand and explain. On top of this, when the synthetic FX hedge returns are used in Investment Analytics Platform - Performance, they are always used on a synthetic FX forward that has two non-zero legs. This might not be the expected behavior if SCD is setup to calculate the returns using a price method that implicitly treats the FX forward as a single-legged instrument. Since these methods are not recommended from a performance perspective, they are removed as calculation options from the Synthetic FX Hedge Return Calculation Settings window. Instead, the four corresponding P/L price methods are added. These are recommended from a performance perspective since they have market value on both legs.

Fixed an error regarding missing "Accepted" events on compliance override request alerts when "Auto release on override" is used. If auto-release is used orders are automatically released and the alert is closed when an override request is accepted, so no "Accepted" event was logged. This fix makes sure an accepted event is logged even if the order is automatically released.

The 'Prepaid fee' is now properly taken into account when calculating accrued fee and cash flows for Trade Manager repos, as well as when calculating the accrued fee in transaction screens for Repos having  the Base value premium calculation 'Clean Price Cash'. The system failed with the assertion error "Unique nominal level holding key expected!" if there is more than one nominal holding key for the same P/L holding key and if the booking across portfolios functionality is used.
The error was corrected by using the cash portfolio instead of the booking portfolio in the P/L framework to find the correct nominal holding.
